abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, with substantial
            institutional development impacts, and satisfactory
            performances by both the Bank, and Borrower. Lessons drawn
            from the project convey primarily that: financial
            sustainability should be a key element in institutional
            strengthening programs; technical assistance (TA) projects
            are more effective if they include an investment component
            in the project's later years; result, and impact
            indicators are important for both project follow-up and
            ex-post evaluation, as well as for managerial
            decision-making; providing upfront procurement, and
            financial management assistance are important partners to
            technical capacity building for sustainability. Furthermore,
            projects should build-in a mechanism for regular
            inter-institutional coordination, and a periodic
            redefinition of roles, and competencies of environmental
            agencies, i.e., for increased effectiveness, and efficiency
            of environmental management, within a particular
            geographical area, there should be only one responsible
            environmental management agency. However, prior evaluation
            of the potential risk of different interpretations of the
            legal framework is fundamental for the design, and execution
            of a project of this nature, in particular if the legal
            framework is relatively recent. In addition, an adequate
            documentation center within institutions, and a related
            dissemination plan are important to create an institutional
            memory, but also to make full use of outputs generated.
